node.text: Jamila is the only Deaf person in her family. But through acts of service and prayer, she discovers that we don’t always need our physical ears to #HearHim.

node.text: Sometimes the voice of the Savior can direct us and those around us in positive ways we didn’t expect. Watch and hear how President @dallinhoaks listened to an impression that blessed him and others. #HearHim

node.title: How I #HearHim: President Dallin H. Oaks

node.text:
“For the past year, we have all been dealing with dramatic and unexpected events. 

“Amid such uncertainty, there is only one way to feel at peace—the real peace that passes all understanding. That peace is found in faith in the Lord Jesus Christ.” — President @russellmnelson 

If you are looking for a place to focus on the Savior this Easter, please join us for Christ-centered messages and music at the worldwide general conference of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

node.title: The Peace and Hope of Easter

node.text: #StartingToday let Jesus Christ change your life. As we prepare to celebrate Easter, learn how He can help you restart and reevaluate. Find renewal and hope in Him. Start today with the link in bio.

node.text:
Verified
“[God] denieth none that come unto him, black and white, bond and free, male and female; and he remembereth the heathen; and all are alike unto God” (2 Nephi 26:33).

See how Calyann put God’s promises in @thebookofmormon to the test, then realized that Jesus Christ’s love is real and available to all.

node.title: Jesus is Real: Calyann's Experience with the Book of Mormon

node.text:
"As members of a global community, we hold hope in our hearts, not only of overcoming the pandemic, but of seeing a brighter future for all children–their parents and their families." —Bishop Gérald Caussé 

The Church announced last week a donation to @unicefusa’s efforts in leading the procurement and supply of 2 billion COVID-19 vaccines around the world by the end of 2021. Our shared commitment is to bless and protect families throughout the world.

node.text: Need a quick activity for your children to teach them about prayer? All you need is this video clip, a pen, paper, and five minutes. Watch with your kids, and look for more ideas to teach your kids about Jesus on the Friend to Friend event on The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints YouTube channel.

node.title: Friend to Friend: Teach Children About Prayer

node.text:
In his 96 years of life, President @russellmnelson of the @churchofjesuschrist has seen almost everything—a Great Depression, a world war, and a global pandemic, to name a few. And he would like to propose one remedy that can help us find joy in hard times: gratitude.​

​Learn more at PowerofGratitude.org. #GiveThanks

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on August 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and dog.

node.text:
"When I didn’t qualify for the finals in the most recent Olympic games, I fell to my knees. I couldn’t have waited through the COVID-19 postponement, been an alternate more than four times, and worked through multiple injuries just to have it all end now. I was devastated. It didn’t feel fair. I was still excited for my teammates, so I prayed for understanding and peace. I felt it almost immediately, even though this huge part of my life was over—or at least I thought it was. As I began to pack my bags, a voice kept telling me it was still my time and things would be okay. I pushed it back, thinking it was false hope, but the voice kept saying, 'It isn’t time to leave. Don’t pack yet.' I listened and waited. And then I got a phone call: my teammate wouldn’t be competing, and I would be taking her spot.

"I’ll never forget taking the floor for the last time. I reflected on the journey to get there, the ups and downs. They had prepared me for this. Without the challenges of the past, I wouldn’t have been able to get there. I needed that refinement. As incredible as it was to get the silver medal, I knew that wasn’t the only goal. I felt an overwhelming impression that I went through all those trials to be a stronger and better example of Jesus Christ. The comfort, courage, and motivation to get up and try again was always from Him. Knowing that I am a daughter of heavenly parents continues to motivate me to never give up and always try my best, no matter the odds. You never know when you will be called upon."—MyKayla
#HearHim

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'The First Presidency Urges Latter-day Saints to Wear Face Masks When N”eded and Get Vaccinated Against COVID-19'.

node.text:
The First Presidency of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints sent the following message today to Church members around the world: 

Dear Brothers and Sisters:

We find ourselves fighting a war against the ravages of COVID-19 and its variants, an unrelenting pandemic. We want to do all we can to limit the spread of these viruses. We know that protection from the diseases they cause can only be achieved by immunizing a very high percentage of the population.

To limit exposure to these viruses, we urge the use of face masks in public meetings whenever social distancing is not possible. To provide personal protection from such severe infections, we urge individuals to be vaccinated.  Available vaccines have proven to be both safe and effective.

We can win this war if everyone will follow the wise and thoughtful recommendations of medical experts and government leaders. Please know of our sincere love and great concern for all of God’s children.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
“I am the youngest in a big family. My older siblings were on their own when I was a teen. I needed a friend. That is when I found Taylor. Our parents were friends, and we became like brothers. We did everything together and helped each other through a lot. Taylor had a heart condition that limited his physical abilities but never seemed to let it get in the way. As he got older he had a heart transplant and things seemed to be going well. I’ll never forget the morning my parents called me in to tell me that Taylor had passed away. I remember going in my room and crying on my bed. I remember laying there and having God speak to me. It wasn’t words; it wasn’t a voice but as if he spoke to me with the feeling of peace. I felt in that moment that our mortal friends and families can be with us again and always because of Jesus Christ. There have been  tough days but I have always felt Him near when I miss that ‘brother.’ That moment and experience has shaped me to live my life in a way that we can see each other again.” —Johnny 

Learn more about the peace Jesus Christ brings when we lose a loved one. Link in bio.

node.text: Jamila is the only Deaf person in her family. But through acts of service and prayer, she discovers that we don’t always need our physical ears to #HearHim.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on July 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, eyeglasses and outdoors.

node.text:
“Several years ago our family moved to Dubai, UAE. I had never lived in a place where the centrality of God in peoples’ lives was so universal. I found it a delight and refreshing to be able to speak about the influence of God and religion in my life without having others discount what I said or become offended. I felt this way because most everyone I met in Dubai spoke as I did, creating an immediate connection as we communicated.

“Sitting by the pool next to another mother, waiting for our children to finish swim practice, I was sharing how I was struggling through some trials and feeling discouraged. This Muslim mother proceeded to offer kind words of encouragement and her assurance that God was watching over us and would help us through our struggles. Not her God. Not my God. Our God.

“My daughter and I were walking to the metro one day and were kindly offered a ride by an Emirati woman, who shared with us experiences about her son who had medical difficulties that required them to travel to the United States for treatment. In the course of her story, her faith in and reliance on God’s will and watchful care was interwoven. I told her I would pray for her and her family, which she accepted with understanding and love.

“When I talked with a Hindu mom whose children my daughter tutored, I heard how central her faith and belief were to her as she told me about how she spends her day in meditation and worship.

“I never once felt uncomfortable being a Christ-believing, God-fearing woman in Dubai. On the contrary, I felt encouraged and strengthened for my beliefs by those I came in contact with. I have not experienced this so universally in any other place I have lived.” —Carol

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on June 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, monument and outdoors.

node.text:
“My childhood home was filled with the stories of my ancestors. I lived every day with the trunk that my great-great-great-grandfather used in his travels and the piano bench from my great-grandmother’s house. The stories I heard from my parents and other family members about our ancestors’ faith, service, love of learning, work ethic, and perseverance in difficult times served as examples of the kind of life I could work towards. History was real for me because I could stand in the places where they had lived, worked, and worshipped. The realness of history has expanded as I have studied and helped preserve those places important to the history of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Standing in the places where generations of Church members have lived, worked, and worshipped has brought holiness to my life. Studying the past has helped shape my path of discipleship.

“I owe much of my ability to do this work of preserving sacred places to Florence Jacobsen. Without her pioneering efforts in the mid-20th century to preserve and share the history of the Church, we would be missing many parts of our story. I frequently ask myself, ‘What would Florence do?’ when researching which stories to share or how to preserve a building. I think of her work ethic as I put in long days covered in dirt or standing in snow. I think of her example of dignified leadership when I am the only woman on a construction site. Her passion for the work of history inspires me to face today’s preservation challenges with the same passion. Florence Jacobsen and my own pioneering ancestors remind me to face the future with hope and compassion as we work together to ‘establish the cause of Zion’ (Doctrine and Covenants 12:6).” —Emily

Follow the link in bio to hear more about Emily on our “Latter-day Saint Women” podcast.

node.text:
“My father and mother were sheep farmers in New Zealand. They enjoyed their life. As a young married couple, they were blessed with three little girls. The youngest of these was named Ann. One day while they were on holiday together at a lake, 17-month-old Ann toddled off. After minutes of desperate searching, she was found lifeless in the water.

“This nightmare caused unspeakable sorrow. Dad wrote years later that some of the laughter went out of their lives forever. It also caused a yearning for answers to life’s most important questions: What will become of our precious Ann? Will we ever see her again? How can our family ever be happy again?

“Some years after this tragedy, two young missionaries from The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints came to our farm. They began teaching the truths found in the Book of Mormon and the Bible. These truths include the assurance that Ann now lives in the spirit world. Because of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ, she too will be resurrected. …

“Many years later Dad told me that if not for Ann’s tragic death, he would never have been humble enough to accept the restored gospel. Yet the Spirit of the Lord instilled hope that what the missionaries taught was true. My parents’ faith continued to grow until they each burned with the fire of testimony that quietly and humbly guided their every decision in life.

“I will always be thankful for my parents’ example to future generations. It is impossible to measure the number of lives forever changed because of their acts of faith in response to profound sorrow.

“I invite all who feel sorrow, all who wrestle with doubt, all who wonder what happens after we die, to place your faith in Christ. I promise that if you desire to believe, then act in faith and follow the whisperings of the Spirit, you will find joy in this life and in the world to come.” —Elder S. Mark Palmer (general conference, Apr. 2021)

Artwork: “Holding Hope,” used with permission from the artist, Jenna McKell

Learn more about what happens as we die at the link in bio.

node.text:
“The role of father is of divine origin, beginning with a Father in Heaven. … We honor those who do all that can be done in love, patience, and self-sacrifice to meet individual and family needs.” —Elder @dtoddchristofferson (general conference, Apr. 2016)

Happy Father’s Day!

May we show gratitude for the men who are the fathers in our lives—this day and always. See more of what we believe about families and the essential role of fathers at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Church of Jesus Christ on June 19, 2021. May be art of 5 people.

node.text:
“I reiterate my call to members of the Church everywhere to abandon attitudes and actions of prejudice and to promote respect for all of God’s children. This is a hallmark of all true followers of Jesus Christ. 

“Abandoning prejudice must go well beyond what we say at the pulpit. We also need to abandon hurtful and insensitive comments in our conversations, in our private messages to one another and on social media, and, most importantly, in our own hearts. This will happen as we fully embrace the teachings of the Savior Jesus Christ, who said, ‘Love one another; as I have loved you’ (John 13:34).” —President @russellmnelson

Earlier this week, the Church announced a collaboration with @naacp and @uncf to work together on academic- and philanthropic-focused plans designed to assist and bless those in need. See the link in bio to learn more about the collaboration and initiatives. #Juneteenth

Artwork used with permission from the artist, Kathleen Peterson.
